subject: Re: RE: [junit] [TEST] JTest v4.5 and what is says about JUnit
msgSnippet: ... [...] ... [...snip examples...] Yes, certainly.  I understand your example of JDBC exceptions, for which the strategy of retrying a few times may be
messageBody:
Quoth Chappell, Simon P:
> >-----Original Message-----
> >From: Steven Taschuk [mailto:staschuk@...]
[...]
> >But why would the calling code care? For example, why would it
> >react differently to an IllegalArgExc than to any random
> >RuntimeException?
>
> Good question. I hope that I can provide a good answer. The reason
> why my code would care about the type of exception raised by the
> code that I have called is that there are some exceptions that are
> non-terminal and that when received, my code will try to do
> something about it. Let's try an example:
[...snip examples...]

Yes, certainly. I understand your example of JDBC exceptions, for
which the strategy of retrying a few times may be appropriate.

But what error-recovery strategy, if any, is appropriate for
IllegalArgExc but inappropriate for other RuntimeExcs? In other
words:
try {
// Some code.
} catch (IllegalArgumentException e) {
// What might be done here ...
} catch (RuntimeException e) {
// ... that wouldn't be equally sensible here?
}
